details.title: Advanced range migration algorithm for ultra-high resolution spaceborne synthetic aperture radar

kwd: ultra-high resolution spaceborne synthetic aperture radar

authors.affiliation: School of Information and Electronic, Beijing Institute of Technology
authors.name: Tao Zeng

authors.affiliation: School of Information and Electronic, Beijing Institute of Technology
authors.name: Wenfu Yang

authors.affiliation: School of Information and Electronic, Beijing Institute of Technology
authors.name: Zegang Ding

authors.affiliation: School of Information and Electronic, Beijing Institute of Technology
authors.name: Luosi Liu

details.abstract: To achieve ultra-high resolution images, processing algorithm of spaceborne synthetic aperture radar (SAR) faces significant challenges such as the curved orbit, the unneglectable propagation time and the space-variant effective velocity. In the light of imaging requirements of the ultra-high resolution spaceborne SAR, an advanced range migration algorithm (ARMA) is presented in this study. Firstly, a new slant range model is developed by incorporating straight orbit approximation with additional linear, cubic and quartic term. Subsequently, a two-dimensional spectrum is derived by making use of Fourier transform pairs and the approximate azimuth stationary point based on the new range model. Finally, a novel RMA is derived. In this algorithm, the accurate range cell migration correction (RCMC) is done through two steps: the effective velocity dependence RCMC and the bulk RCMC, and the range-variant azimuth filtering is accomplished. Simulations are carried out to verify our proposed algorithm, which indicate that ARMA can keep precise even the resolution is up to decimeter level.

ieee.title: A High-Order Imaging Algorithm for High-Resolution Spaceborne SAR Based on a Modified Equivalent Squint Range Model
ieee.displayText: Pengbo Wang, Wei Liu, Jie Chen, Mu Niu, Wei Yang, "A High-Order Imaging Algorithm for High-Resolution Spaceborne SAR Based on a Modified Equivalent Squint Range Model", Geoscience and Remote Sensing IEEE Transactions on, vol. 53, pp. 1225-1235, 2015, ISSN 0196-2892.
